title: An Iraq War Vet Just Tweeted An Amazing Story About How An Iraqi Refugee Touched His Life
text:
— odp (@dyllyp) January 28, 2017 
Brahim's family lacked the most basic necessities – the things most people might take for granted. One day, Park-Pettiford, recalls, he brought Brahim and his family a few essential toiletries from the PX, including soap. "When I presented it to him, he cried," Part-Pettiford tweeted. "Literally bawled his eyes out and said he give his life for me. OVER SOAP. Completely sobering." 
Brahim served as an interpreter and liaison for Park-Pettiford and his fellow airmen for a year, "essentially saving (their) lives on a daily basis" as he recalls. 
When Park-Pettiford's deployment was up, he had a feeling he'd never see the teenager again. At the end of my tour in Iraq, I knew I was leaving him to die. I knew I'd never see him again. Was just kinda like "take care kid." 
A few years later, Park-Pettiford was out of the military. He found himself on his way from Hawaii to Arizona after his brother was murdered during a carjacking. 
Upon landing in Arizona, Park-Pettiford got into a cab at the airport. I get in the first taxi that pulls up and we're off. Driver starts to make the standard small talk. Where you from, what do you do, etc.
